newsitem.title: NEW ZEALAND: NZ student makes stink to stop fierce dogs.
newsitem.headline: NZ student makes stink to stop fierce dogs.

text.p: A New Zealander has developed a spray that smells so bad it scares off aggressive dogs.
Called Skunk Shot because the chemicals used replicate those excreted by a skunk, it works best sprayed in the dog's face.
It has been given the thumbs up by the local animal protection body, the Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals (SPCA).
Wellington's Evening Post newspaper said on Friday that physics graduate Andrew Rakich had developed the product as he made coffee in his kitchen.
"I was feeling a little low, I'd broken up with my girlfriend and also broken my ankle on the same day... and then I had this idea," he said.
Animal control officer Shirley Tyler said authorities near Wellington had conducted successful trials of the spray, which is now being marketed by a retail chain.
"The beauty of it, and the guy demonstrates it on himself, is that it doesn't hurt the animal," she said.
Rakich is now working on a spray to fend off people, one with a smell that will linger for days.
"We'll end up with the police saying 'have you smelt this man' and putting out scratch and sniff wanted posters," Rakich said.
